column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Scorpia ( journalist )
#Text=Scorpia
#Text=is the pseudonym of a video game journalist who was active from the early 1980s through the late 1990s .
#Text=She wrote for Computer Gaming World , performing reviews on role-playing video games and adventure games .
#Text=Scorpia was known for harsh criticism of video games she disliked .
#Text=She was fired after CGW was sold to Ziff-Davis in 1999 and subsequently retired from games journalism .
#Text=Her pseudonym is based on a character she created in a role-playing game .
#Text=Career
#Text=Scorpia became interested in computers after attending a computer expo .
#Text=Her initial intention was to become a programmer , and she said she bought her first computer games to learn how to program . [ 1 ]
#Text=In November 1982 , while working as a data processing consultant , Scorpia co-founded an early gaming-related Special Interest Group on CompuServe .
#Text=It became the eighth most popular forum on CompuServe , and Scorpia received free access to the subscription service in return for maintaining it . [ 2 ]
#Text=As a system operator , she ran online conferences and hosted games . [ 3 ]
#Text=The following year , Computer Gaming World ( CGW ) owner Russell Sipe contacted her on CompuServe and invited her to write for the magazine .
#Text=Scorpia agreed , though she had never read it . She reviewed role-playing video games and adventure games there for 16 years . [ 1 ]
#Text=Scorpia became a prominent reviewer in the industry .

#Text=In addition to her writing and online presence , she provided hints to players who contacted her through a post office box . [ 4 ] [ 5 ] CGW billed her as " controversial " , [ 1 ] and often published a Scorpia review together with another of the same game by a different reviewer . [ 6 ]
#Text=She became known for harsh criticism of video games she disliked .
#Text=Scorpia 's review of Ultima VIII : Pagan was highlighted by GameSetWatch as one of the harshest video game reviews ever written . [ 7 ]
#Text=Her review of Might and Magic II : Gates to Another World resulted in an angry response from the game 's designer , Jon Van Caneghem , who named a monster after Scorpia in his next game . [ 8 ]
#Text=While usually a fan of Infocom , she so disliked Infidel that she never mentioned it in print , although lambasting the game during an online chat with creator Mike Berlyn . [ 4 ]
#Text=CGW
#Text=editor Johnny Wilson described Scorpia as " one of the most refreshing people you could ever meet " and praised her encyclopedic knowledge of games ' puzzles .
#Text=He cited one example where the two clashed , the role-playing game Darklands .
#Text=Scorpia wrote a negative review that criticized the game 's bugs , and Wilson attached an editorial sidebar that gave a more positive view .
#Text=Wilson later acknowledged this was a bad idea , saying that Scorpia 's fans correctly criticized him for undercutting her review and overlooking the game 's flaws .

#Text=Because the magazine required a reviewer to finish the game before publishing the review , Wilson said Scorpia favored linearity , resulting in unwarranted criticism of some open-ended works ; CGW thus sometimes did not assign her such games . [ 9 ]
#Text=Scorpia was fired after CGW was sold to Ziff Davis in 1999 .
#Text=She said it was intimated to her that the magazine wanted to go in a different direction .
#Text=She neither looked for further work in games journalism nor received any offers ; she attributed her reputation for tough reviews as one possible reason for the latter . [ 10 ]
#Text=Scorpia started a subscription webzine after this , but it failed when she could not find enough subscribers . [ 11 ]
#Text=She subsequently started a free website , where she blogged . [ 1 ]
#Text=She stopped updating the site in 2009 after saying that she was unable to afford a new computer needed to keep reviewing games . [ 12 ]
#Text=Personal life
#Text=Her pseudonym comes from role-playing games and is based on her astrological sign of Scorpio . [ 1 ]
#Text=She said she was already known as Scorpia because of her work in online communities and found it " more fitting " than her real name for her focus on role-playing games and adventure games .
#Text=She values her privacy and cited that as another reason for using a pseudonym . [ 10 ]
#Text=At CGW , only owner Sipe knew her real name . [ 9 ]
#Text=Her favorite video game is Ultima IV : Quest of the Avatar . [ 1 ]
